title: Voltage Distribution in the Windings of Medium-Frequency Transformers Operated With Wide Bandgap Devices
abstract: The short rise time observed in the PWM voltages generated by ultrafast wide bandgap devices increases the amplitude of voltage harmonics at higher frequencies. These harmonics can excite the resonances of medium-frequency transformers (MFTs), resulting in overvoltages inside the windings during continuous operation. Without further measures, these overvoltages can lead to unexpectedly high electric fields in the insulation material, which can result in partial discharge, accelerated aging, and possible failure of the MFT. To avoid these effects, the mechanism causing the overvoltages has to be understood and quantified during the design process. Based on this, the MFT can be designed in a way that the overvoltages vanish or are tolerable. Therefore, the voltage distribution inside the MFT windings is analyzed by a fully coupled multiconductor transmission line model, which includes the damping effect of electromagnetic losses in the litz wire and the core. This method is verified by measuring the transfer functions of the voltage to ground of individual turns and their voltage waveforms during continuous operation. The waveforms indicate repeating overvoltages inside the windings. A guideline for the design verification and a simplified approach to speed-up the modeling process are presented.

V oltage Distribution in the Windings of
Medium-Frequency Transformers
Operated With Wide Bandgap Devices
Andrea Cremasco , Student Member, IEEE, Daniel Rothmund , Student Member, IEEE,
Mitrofan Curti , Member, IEEE, and Elena A. Lomonova,Senior Member, IEEE
Abstract— The short rise time observed in the PWM volt-
ages generated by ultrafast wide bandgap devices increases the
amplitude of voltage harmonics at higher frequencies. These
harmonics can excite the resonances of medium-frequency trans-
formers (MFTs), resulting in overvoltages inside the windings
during continuous operation. Without further measures, these
overvoltages can lead to unexpectedly high electric ﬁelds in
the insulation material, which can result in partial discharge,
accelerated aging, and possible failure of the MFT. To avoid
these effects, the mechanism causing the overvoltages has to be
understood and quantiﬁed during the design process. Based on
this, the MFT can be designed in a way that the overvoltages
vanish or are tolerable. Therefore, the voltage distribution inside
the MFT windings is analyzed by a fully coupled multiconductor
transmission line model, which includes the damping effect of
electromagnetic losses in the litz wire and the core. This method
is veriﬁed by measuring the transfer functions of the voltage
to ground of individual turns and their voltage waveforms
during continuous operation. The waveforms indicate repeating
overvoltages inside the windings. A guideline for the design
veriﬁcation and a simpliﬁed approach to speed-up the modeling
process are presented.
Index Terms—H i g h dv/dt, high-frequency model, insulation,
medium-frequency transformer (M FT), solid-state transformer
(SST), wide bandgap (WBG) devices.
I. I NTRODUCTION
I
N RECENT years, the need for highly efﬁcient interfaces
between the medium-voltage (MV) ac grid and the low-
voltage (LV) dc buses has signiﬁcantly increased hand in hand
with the rapidly growing amount of high-power LV dc loads
and sources [1]–[7]. In such a scenario, so-called solid-state
transformers (SSTs), i.e., galvanically insulated high-power
ac/dc, dc/dc, and dc/ac converters, could replace the state-
of-the-art technology based on low-frequency transformers

(LFTs) due to several beneﬁts, such as lower volume and
weight [8]–[10]. An exhaustive overview of the typical con-
nection schemes utilized to interface the SST to the grid is
provided in [8] and [10].
One of the components essential for fulﬁlling the voltage
conversion and the galvanic insulation of the SST is the
medium-frequency transformer (MFT). The MFT is a trans-
former operated with pulsewidth modulation (PWM) voltage
waveforms in the kilohertz range and the MV level. The
most common alternatives toconnect the MFT to the power
electronics are presented in [11]. The operating voltage level of
the MFTs typically results in similar insulation requirements
as LFTs, to guarantee the same operational safety within the
MV grid. The insulation level considered for the design of
recent MFTs is shown in Fig. 1 [12]–[14]; designs from
[21]–[23] and [25] are operated with SiC semiconductor
devices. A positive trend is observed both in the number of
MV prototypes realized in recent years and in the insulation
level being considered. However, the declared insulation rating
does not always align with the testing procedures prescribed
by the international standards [26], [27], i.e., partial discharge
(PD) and lightning impulse (LI) test. Therefore, the effective
insulation performance of these prototypes cannot be easily
compared.

3588 IEEE JOURNAL OF EMERGING AND SELECTED TOPICS IN POWER ELECTRONICS, VOL. 10, NO. 4, AUGUST 2022
Due to their much higher operating frequency, MFTs are
signiﬁcantly more compact than LFTs for the same transferred
power. Nonetheless, since the required insulation rating is
independent of the speciﬁc transformer technology, the insu-
lation thickness between the primary and secondary sides
would be equal for both the MFT and the LFT. This leads
to the situation that the galvanic insulation system of an
MFT occupies a much larger portion of the transformer’s
volume compared to an LFT, or in other words, the room
for additional design margins is drastically reduced for MFTs.
Therefore, during the design stage, it is highly important to
know the electric ﬁeld stresses inside the insulation system
to guarantee safe operation under all expected conditions
while achieving the highest possible transformer performance,
i.e., high efﬁciency and power density.
During its lifetime, the MFT has to withstand the electric
ﬁeld stresses resulting from the PWM voltage applied by the
converter during normal operation [28], [29] and those coming
from the very fast and short-term overvoltages, e.g., when
an MV overhead line is hit by a lightning strike [20], [21].
Therefore, the design is aimed to limit the maximum electric
ﬁeld below the dielectric strength of the insulating materials.
This limit can be characterized experimentally for the long-
term stability, e.g., by voltage endurance test and breakdown
test with impulse voltage [30]–[34]. The assessment of the
stresses in the insulation is performed by evaluating the
electric ﬁeld distribution and the dielectric losses [35], [36],
which both require to determine the voltage in the active
parts.
In contrast to LFTs, MFTs are permanently exposed to fast
transients, both during normal operation, especially when they
are operated with wide bandgap (WBG) devices, and in the
case of a lightning strike. Furthermore, the rise time of a PWM
voltage generated by WBG semiconductor devices can be
signiﬁcantly faster than an LI due to their superior switching
characteristics compared to silicon-based devices [26], [37],
[38]. These fast transients lead to a nonuniform voltage distrib-
ution along the windings caused by voltage propagation delays
and/or the excitation of resonances between the distributed
capacitances and inductances of the winding. Nevertheless,
the design for continuous PWM operation and long-term stress
is performed assuming a uniform distribution, as it is con-
sidered in LFTs; hence, high-frequency effects are normally
neglected [39]–[41]. However, if the design of an MFT does
not account for these effects, the high-frequency harmonic
of the PWM can excite the internal resonances of the MFT
windings, resulting in repetitive ringing overvoltages during
normal operation. These overvoltages can intensify the electric
ﬁeld beyond the dielectric strength of the insulation, leading
to the inception of PD and, therefore, reducing the lifetime of
the transformer [28], [30], [42], [43].
To quantify the frequency and the amplitude of these
resonant overvoltages, a model of the MFT has to be set up.
The high-frequency effects of surge voltages on the voltage
distribution in the windings of transformers are historically
known [44], and they can be computed by solving 3-D full-
Maxwell equations [45]. Network models based on fully
coupled multiconductor transmission lines (MTLs) are often
adopted in the literature [46]–[52] due to the reduced compu-
tational cost compared to [45].
An MFT with multiple windings is considered in [53],
where a purely capacitive network model is used to compute
the voltage distribution of an LI. In the case of a PWM
waveform, this model could predict only the initial voltage
distribution in correspondence to the transition instant, but
it cannot reproduce the subsequent oscillations due to the
discharge of the parasitic capacitances through the inductive
network [44]. The voltage distribution in the inductors of an
SST is computed in [51]. However, the measurement of the
voltage distribution inside the winding is not performed, and
a detailed description of a suitable modeling procedure, espe-
cially for litz wire, is not provided since windings consisting
of foil and round conductors are analyzed.
One of the main challenges for the MTL method is the
estimation of the frequency-dependent parameters, describing
the dissipative effects due to ohmic and core losses. These
parameters need to be computed as accurately as possible
since they affect both the amplitude and the decay time of
the oscillating overvoltages. The dissipative phenomena in
the winding of a transformer are represented by a diagonal
resistance matrix in [49]. This representation is effective in
the case of a standard two-winding transformer, but it is not
suitable for describing the dissipative effects in multiwind-
ing transformers [54], which are often used for multiport
SSTs [11], [19], [54]. A full resistance matrix is introduced
in [52], but the nondiagonal terms account only for eddy
current losses in the core since a standard two-winding LFT
is considered. In [48], the skin effect is considered, whereas
proximity losses are neglected. An efﬁcient method for foil and
wire conductors is introduced in [50], but it does not apply
to the litz of MFTs. Ohmic losses in litz wires are accurately
computed by electromagnetic ﬁeld analysis by homogenization
and complex magnetic permeability [55], [56].
The computation of the voltage distribution inside the wind-
ings of MFTs during continuous operation requires further
investigations, and to the best of our knowledge, no experi-
mental proof is provided in the literature. Therefore, this article
presents a modeling procedure to include these effects in the
design process of MFTs to prevent unexpected overvoltages
due to the unprecedented rise time of WBG devices. The out-
comes of this work are proposed to overcoming the challenges
in increasing the insulation levels of SSTs operated with WBG
technologies.
In Section II, the correlation between the rise time and
the harmonic content of a PWM waveform is recalled. The
method of MTL is extended to cover litz wire conductors.
A full frequency-dependent resistance matrix is computed
by the ﬁnite element method (FEM) and homogenization
of the litz bundle. The computation of the inductance and
capacitance matrices by FEM is discussed in the same section.
In Section III, the MFT used in the experimental setup and
the veriﬁcation of the model are presented. Results indicate
signiﬁcant overvoltages that have been measured at individual
winding turns. The effect of these overvoltages on the electric
ﬁeld in the interturn and interlayer insulation of the MFT is
discussed. Finally, Section IV presents guidelines to mitigate

II. H IGH -FREQUENCY MODEL OF THE MFT
To formulate the high-frequency model of the MFT, it is
necessary to identify the frequency spectrum of a PWM
voltage waveform, which is the input of the MTL model. The
parameters of the MTL model are deﬁned and computed by
the FEM model of the MFT.
A. Frequency Spectrum of a PWM Waveform
The ﬁrst step in the analysis of the high-frequency effects
occurring in an MFT is the evaluation of the harmonic
spectrum of the PWM voltage being applied. The bandwidth of
a nonstationary signal strongly depends on how fast its transi-
tions occur. Usually, the fastest voltage transitions experienced
by a conventional LFT are due to the occurrence of a lightning
strike, for which a rise time of 1.2 µs is considered [26]. As a
consequence, the design of the insulation of an LFT subject
to an LI requires analyzing high-frequency phenomena, such
as impulse propagation delays or the excitation of transformer
resonances [49], [50]. These effects are normally neglected
during the design of the insulation of an MFT operated with
PWM voltage waveforms [39]–[41]. Nevertheless, the rise
time of a PWM voltage generated by WBG semiconductor
devices can be even shorter than 1.2 µs [37], [38].
In the case of a symmetric PWM voltage with fundamental
frequency f

B. Fully Coupled MTL Model of the MFT
The effects of the high-frequency harmonics on the voltage
distribution in the MFT during continuous operation are com-
puted in the frequency domain by the MTL model described
in [48], [49]. This approach is based on the discretization of the
electromagnetic ﬁeld equations by a fully coupled multicon-
ductor transmission line network, in which the mutual coupling
between all the turns in the windings is considered [46],
[47]. It is a reasonable assumption to model each turn as
electrically small [57] since the shortest wavelength in the
harmonic spectrum of the PWM voltages being considered is
signiﬁcantly longer than the turn in the MFT. As a result,
the elementary entities constituting the network model of the
transformer are the single turns of the winding system. With
this representation, both the currents and the voltages are
assumed uniform within their respective turn. To exemplify,
Fig. 3 represents the cross section and the corresponding
network model of a simpliﬁed MFT with 3 : 3 turns ratio
between its primary (HV) and secondary (LV) windings. This
model consists of the following:
1) self and mutual resistances that are used to model the
losses in the MFT, i.e., the ohmic losses due to the skin
and the proximity effects and the losses in the core [54];
2) self and mutual inductances that represent the energy
stored in the magnetic ﬁeld and the magnetic coupling
between the turns;
3) capacitors that describe the energy stored in the electric
ﬁeld in the interturn, interwinding, and turn-to-ground
insulation.
As shown in Fig. 3, the voltages applied to the windings
of the MFT are represented by ideal voltage sources. This
approximation is reasonable if the voltage waveforms applied
to the MFT during operation are known. Otherwise, these
voltage sources should be substituted by an equivalent model
of the converter to determine the waveforms resulting from
the coupling effect between the converter and the MFT. In
this work, the voltage waveforms applied to the terminals of

It is worth mentioning that (5)can be formulated also in the

The saturation of the core is not included in the model since
the MFT is normally designed to be operated in the linear
region of the B–H curve.
The effect of dielectric dissipation in the insulation is
not considered in the model since MV MFTs are normally
designed with insulating materials characterized by low dielec-
tric loss tangent tanδ [36], [41]. This design choice is aimed to
prevent the thermal runaway of the MFT insulation stressed
by MV PWM waveforms in the kilohertz range [36], [60].
Therefore, as measured in [36], the dissipative phenomena
in the MFT during normal load operation are dominated by
electromagnetic losses in the winding and in the core. This
approximation leads to only minor overestimations of the volt-
age amplitudes predicted by the MTL model, even if materials
with conservatively high dielectric losses are considered. This
is conﬁrmed by the analysis in Appendix B, where the voltage
distribution in an MFT is predicted by including also the
effects of the dielectric losses. Therefore, the conductance of
the insulation of the MFT can be reasonably neglected in the
model.
To recapitulate, the voltage distribution inside the windings
of the MFT is analyzed according to the steps illustrated in the
ﬂowchart in Fig. 4. These steps can be summarized as follows.
1) The harmonic spectrum of the source voltages applied
to the MFT is obtained by the Fourier transform.
2) The MTL model of the MFT is deﬁned by computing
its parameters:
a) the matrices K, H,a n dT;
b) the matrices R and L for every frequencyω of the
source voltage spectrum;
c) the matrix C.
3) The harmonic spectrum of the turn voltagesv is obtained
from (5).
4) The waveform of each turn voltage is synthesized in
the time domain by the inverse Fourier transform of the
corresponding spectrum.
C. RLC Parameters of the Model
The RLC parameters of the model are obtained by FEM,
which is used to solve the magneto quasi-static (MQS) and
the electrostatic (ES) ﬁeld equations. The MQS ﬁeld equation
is used to compute theRL parameters, whereas the ES ﬁeld
equation is solved for obtaining the C parameters. The 3-D
FEM analysis needs to be applied when no 2-D equivalent sim-
pliﬁcation is possible, e.g., when additional conductive or fer-
romagnetic elements are located in the vicinity of the MFT,
such as enclosures and electromagnetic shields. The impact
of these structures on the RLC parameters of the MFT can
be signiﬁcant, so it has to be included in the FEM model.
However, this is not the case for the MFT prototype considered
in this work, where no enclosures or electromagnetic shields
are present.

Several methods are proposed in the literature to circumvent
computationally expensive 3-D FEM simulations, by com-
bining the results obtained by equivalent 2-D models. The
simpliﬁcation approach has to be chosen considering the
geometry of the windings and the core of the MFT. As
discussed in Section III, an MFT prototype with E-core and
rectangular winding is built in this work for measuring the
voltage distribution in the winding and verifying experimen-
tally the MTL model. For this case, the “Double 2-D” method
described in [61] can be adopted for computing the MQS
and ES ﬁeld equations by combining 2-D planar models. This
method is veriﬁed in [61] only for the equivalent parameters
of transformers without air gaps in the core, considering leak-
age excitation, i.e., when equal and opposite magnetomotive
forces (MMFs) are generatedby its windings. This method is
characterized by possibly limited accuracy in the computation
of the equivalentRL parameters during magnetizing excitation,
especially in the case of cores with large air gaps and,
therefore, high magnetizing currents. However, no large air
gaps are present in the core of the MFT prototype considered
in this work, so the magnetizing currents are limited, as well
as their impact on the voltage distribution inside the winding.
The “Double 2-D” method presented in [61] and adopted
in this work for computing theRLC parameters of the MTL
model is recalled.
1) Double 2-D Method:The MQS and the ES ﬁeld equa-
tions used to compute the RLC parameters are solved by
FEM using the “Double 2-D” technique presented in [61].
This method is based on the solution of two 2-D problems
(Double 2-D) to analyze 3-D structures. The results of the
two 2-D problems are obtained considering the cross sections

2) RL Parameters: The matrices R and L are frequency-

range [62]. This affects both the magnetic coupling in the
winding and the power dissipated in the core. Both matrices
are computed at each angular frequencyω solving Maxwell’s

the matrices R and L are computed by the Double 2-D FEM
modeling approach described in Section II-C1. As described
in [63], the elements of the resistance and inductance matrices
are calculated by integrating the electromagnetic loss and the
magnetic ﬁeld energy densities computed by the FEM model,

The frequency-dependent complex permeability of the core
μ
Fe = μ′
Fe − jμ′′
Fe is used to include the dissipative effect of
the electromagnetic losses in the ferrite. This representation
excludes the necessity to model the eddy current in the core
material, which is assigned zero conductivity. The complex
permeability is estimated in this work by using the character-
istic curves available from the datasheet of the corresponding
material [62]. As discussed in [64], [65], a portion of the
electromagnetic losses described by the complex permeability
is caused by eddy current, displacement current, and the
effect of dimensional resonances in ferrite. These phenomena
are affected by the size of the core. Therefore, the accurate
characteristic curve of complex permeability has to be deﬁned,
for example, according to measurements on the core being
used. As observed in the experimental veriﬁcation presented in
Section III, using the characteristic curves from the datasheet
can lead to reasonably accurate voltage distributions, but the
limited validity of this approach is recognized.
The litz bundle is homogenized in the FEM model. Homog-
enization allows computing skin and proximity losses in the
litz wire without representing explicitly the eddy currents in
each individual strand [56]. This approach reduces drastically
the computational effort since the skin depth of the litz strands
does not need to be discretized. The litz strands are assumed
perfectly twisted, so the current sharing between them is equal.
Therefore, a uniform current density is applied [55], [56],
[66]. The equivalent conductivity and complex permeability
of the homogenized litz are discussed in [56]. Alternative
methods to compute the equivalent properties representing
ohmic losses due to skin and proximity effect are described in
the literature [55], [56], [66]–[69]. The formulation proposed
in [56] is chosen for its proven accuracy.
For each frequency, the entries of the full matrix R are
computed as described in [54], and the resulting matrix R
is a full-matrix whose nondiagonal terms are called mutual
resistances. As demonstrated in [54], the mutual resistances
in (5) provide a more generalized description of the proximity
losses in the model of the transformer.

where ε is the permittivity. The insulation permittivity can
be reasonably assumed as constant in the frequency range of
interest [36]. In the model, the core is considered grounded,
and the effect of displacement current and dielectric losses
is not included. The ES ﬁeld equation and the matrix C
are computed by the Double 2-D FEM modeling approach
described in Section II-C1. The elements of the capacitance
matrix are deﬁned according to [58]; as described in [63],
the capacitances are calcula ted by integrating the energy

III. M EASUREMENTS AND VERIFICATION
The voltage distribution in the winding of the MFT and
the accuracy of the MTL model are analyzed in this Section.
An MFT prototype is built for experimental veriﬁcation. First,
a sweep frequency response analysis (SFRA) is performed
to measure the transfer functions of the turn voltages and
evaluate the accuracy of the model for individual frequencies.
Several peaks in the voltage transfer functions are observed.
The origin of these overvoltages is investigated by measuring
the impedance of the HV and LV windings. Next, the MFT is
operated with a symmetric PWM waveform to verify the MTL
model. The occurrence of internal overvoltages is analyzed for
different rise times in the PWM waveform. Finally, the impact
of these overvoltages on the electric ﬁeld stresses in the
insulation is discussed.
A. MFT Prototype for the Experimental Setup
The MFT considered for this analysis is shown in Fig. 6(a).
The coil consists of an inner secondary winding (LV) and an
outer primary winding (HV), radially stacked to the LV wind-
ing, as shown in Fig. 6(b). The turns ratio isN = 2:1 ,a n d
the design parameters relevant for the analysis are summarized
in Table I . The HV winding is split into two equal layers,
insulated by two 0.5 mm Nomex foils.
The cross section of the 3C94 ferrite core allows operating
the MFT in the linear region of the B–H curve, at 20 kHz,
for voltages up to at least 1 kV. The effect of the magnetic
relaxation on the permeability of the core is taken into account
by the frequency-dependent characteristic of the complex
permeability of the material [62].
The voltage distribution inside both the HV and the LV
windings is monitored by measuring the voltage to ground
of several winding turns. The notation adopted to indicate a
turn consists of two capital letters and a number referring to
the winding and the position of the turn, respectively, e.g.,
the ﬁrst turn of the HV winding is indicated as HV1. The
internal voltage of the windingis made accessible by soldering

critical since the fundamental frequency at which the MFT
operates is well belowf

at this frequency to cause dangerous overvoltages inside the
winding. As shown in the same plots, the MTL model follows
this phenomenon with good agreement, for all the turns being
considered, both for amplitudes and phases.
To investigate the origin of this voltage ampliﬁcation,
the short-circuit impedance of the MFT seen from the HV
side ZHV,sc is measured by the Agilent/HP 4294A Precision
Impedance Analyzer, to observe if any resonance is visible.
The measured impedance and the connection diagram illus-
trating the free terminals of the MFT at which the impedance
is measured are shown in Fig. 8. The parallel resonance at
3.2 MHz does not cause overvoltages, so it is out of the scope
of this analysis. The ﬁrst series resonance frequency occurs
in correspondence to fs; therefore, this resonance causes
the voltage ampliﬁcation observed in Fig. 6. To understand
where the resonance occurs, the self-impedances of the HV
winding Z
HV,0 and the LV windingZLV,0 are measured. The
LV winding impedance ZLV,0 does not exhibit any series
resonance near 3.6 MHz, whereas the ﬁrst series resonance
of ZHV,0 coincides with fs. This indicates that the resonance
observed in the transfer functions is internal to the HV winding
and that the frequency of this resonance is not sensitive to the
presence of the LV winding. Besides, the voltage ampliﬁcation
observed in T
LV7 is not caused by a resonance internal to the
LV winding but is due to the electromagnetic coupling with
the HV winding.

IV . D
ESIGN GUIDELINES
The following guidelines recall possible strategies to mit-
igate the internal overvoltages observed in Section III and
provide a simpliﬁed modeling approach for the veriﬁcation
of routine designs.
A. Prevention of Ringing Overvoltages During Continuous
PWM Operation
The detrimental effects of the ringing overvoltages observed
in Section III can be prevented by ensuring that the harmonic
content of the PWM is low enough in correspondence to the
series resonance frequency of the MFT. In this way, the ampli-
ﬁcation of the harmonics in the turn voltage caused by the
winding resonance does not introduce critical overvoltages. In
other words, enough margin must be guaranteed between the
corner frequency of the PWM spectrumf
c and fs.
Regarding the design of the power electronics, fc can be
varied modifying tr and, therefore, dv/dt of the switches:
1) in the case of soft-switching operation, d v/dt can
be decreased by reducing the current being switched,
e.g., by increasing the magnetizing inductance of the
MFT or by adding a capacitor in parallel to every
converter switch;
2) in the case of hard-switching operation, active gate
control techniques are proposed in [72] and [73].
Concerning the MFT, the series resonance f
s can be
increased by limiting the parasitic capacitance of the winding.
1) The simplest way to reduce the parasitic capacitances
is by increasing the insulation distances. Even though
this design choice can be easily implemented, it has the
drawback of limiting both the heat dissipation and the
compactness of the winding.
2) A comparison between the standard winding stratiﬁca-
tion used in the prototype shown in Fig. 6 and other
conﬁgurations is performed in [74]. Although the para-
sitic capacitance of the s-winding is approximately 10%
lower than the standard winding, this conﬁguration is
more complex from the manufacturing perspective.
3) An inductor featuring a chambered arrangement of the
winding turns is considered in [23]. It is characterized
by approximately 40% lower parasitic capacitance than
a standard winding construction.
The last option seems an optimal solution since the manufac-
turing complexity of a chambered winding is not signiﬁcantly
higher than the standard one.
B. High-Frequency Model of the MFT for Routine Design
The main challenge for this design veriﬁcation remains the
estimation of f
s of the series resonance under investigation
and, possibly, the ampliﬁcation factor of the PWM harmon-
ics causing ringing overvoltages. Although this task can be
performed very accurately by the MTL model, this method
might be too demanding for routine analyses since it requires
the calculation of large matrices for different frequencies in
the bandwidth of interest. Existing high-frequency models for
transformer design are normally developed focusing the atten-
tion on the parallel resonances of the coil and their detrimental
effects on current waveforms, both for the converter and the
passive components [75], [76]. Therefore, a simpliﬁed model

V. C
ONCLUSION
This article highlights the implications of using WBG
devices on the electric stress in the insulation of MFTs by
analyzing the occurrence of overvoltages inside the windings
resulting from the fast rise time in the PWM voltage. The
voltage distribution inside the winding of the transformer is
modeled by a multiconductor fully coupled transmission line
model.
The model is extended by thefrequency-dependent induc-
tance and resistance matrices. Both matrices are computed by
the FEM, modeling the litz wire with an equivalent complex
permeability and electrical conductivity to include proximity
and skin effect losses, respectively. The method is veriﬁed
experimentally by measuring the transfer functions of the
voltage to the ground of single turns by the SFRA and the
voltage to the ground during continuous operation with a
converter. The maximum deviation between the measured and
the computed ringing overvoltage peaks is 5.0% and 19.0%
in the HV and LV winding turns, respectively.
The results indicate repetitive overvoltages in the interturn
insulation of both the HV and LV windings during normal
operation. When the rise time of the PWM voltage is reduced
to 54 ns, the overvoltage occurring inside the interlayer insu-
lation of the HV winding reaches 1.6 times the amplitude of
the PWM voltage applied at the terminals of the transformer.
These overvoltages can increase the electric ﬁeld beyond the
dielectric strength of the insulation, leading to the inception
of PD and, therefore, reducing the lifetime of the transformer.
To prevent this scenario, several guidelines are proposed,
together with a simpliﬁed modeling approach that can be
applied for speeding up the design veriﬁcation process. The
outcomes of this work can contribute to overcome the design
challenges in integrating WBG devices with MFTs and meet
the MV insulation requirements of SSTs interfacing the ac/dc
distribution grid of the future.

APPENDIX B
SENSITIVITY ANALYSIS ON DIELECTRIC LOSSES
The dissipative effect introduced by the dielectric losses
in the insulation of the MFT can reduce the amplitude of
the high-frequency overvoltages observed in Section III. This
appendix presents the evaluation of the sensitivity between the
peak of the voltage waveforms computed by the MTL model
of an MFT and the dielectric losses in the insulation.
The dissipative effect of dielectric losses can be included in
the MTL model by introducing in (5) a conductance matrixG

Fig. 16. Normalized peak voltage to ground ˆv of individual turns, showing

The method to compute C is described in Section II,
whereas tan δ can be extracted from the datasheet of the
insulating material or by measurements [36].
The analysis is performed considering theRLC parameters
of the MFT prototype described in Section III. The effect of
dielectric losses is evaluated by analyzing the proﬁles of the
peak values of the voltage to the ground ˆv of individual turns
in the HV winding during continuous operation. The peak volt-
ages are compared when the MTL model is computed without
including dielectric losses (tan δ = 0) and when dielectric
losses are considered up to a tanδ = 0.05. tanδ is assumed
constant in the whole frequency spectrum. tanδ covered by the
sensitivity analysis is representative of the insulating materials
normally considered for MV MFTs, as discussed in [36] and
[41] and recalled in Table III.
The voltage distribution in the HV winding is illustrated
in Fig. 16; the turn numbering and voltage normalization
are explained in Section III. The reference PWM voltage
waveforms W2 and W3 are considered since W1 does not
originate critical overvoltages. As observed, even a relatively
high amount of dielectric losses cause only minor deviations in
the voltage distributions predicted by the model. The highest
3600 IEEE JOURNAL OF EMERGING AND SELECTED TOPICS IN POWER ELECTRONICS, VOL. 10, NO. 4, AUGUST 2022
deviation is 3.0% when tanδ = 0.05 and waveform W3 is con-
sidered (tr = 54 ns), whereas no signiﬁcant impact is observed
for waveform W2 (tr = 194 ns). It is worth remarking that
tan δ = 0.05 is a quite high value for MFT insulation; hence,
it is a conservative limit for this analysis. As shown in [36],
a thermal runaway in the MFT insulation can already occur
in an insulating material with lower tanδ = 0.01 − 0.02 and
stressed with PWM waveforms having rise times longer than
W2. Therefore, the conductance matrix G representing the
dielectric losses in the insulation can be reasonably neglected
in (B.16). This assumption does not lead to unsafe design
choices, e.g., underdimensioning of the insulation, with the
advantage of reducing the parameters to determine in the MTL
model, i.e., avoid frequency-dependent EQS ﬁeld analyses.

Andrea Cremasco (Student Member, IEEE)
received the M.Sc. degree(cum laude) in electrical
engineering from the University of Pavia, Pavia,
Italy, in 2014. In the same year, he joined the ABB
Corporate Research Center, Baden, Switzerland, for
his graduation project.
From 2015 to 2018, he was with ABB Schweiz
AG, Lugano, Switzerland, where he worked as a
Research and Development Engineer on power trans-
formers and reactors. In 2018, he joined the Group
of Electromechanics and Power Electronics at the
Eindhoven University of Technology, Eindhoven, The Netherlands, where
he is currently pursuing the Ph.D. degree. His current research interests
include electromagnetic modeling of magnetic components for MV solid-state
transformers and charge transport modeling in their insulation.
Daniel Rothmund (Student Member, IEEE)
received the M.Sc. degree in electrical engineering
and information technology from ETH Zürich,
Zürich, Switzerland, in 2013, with a focus on power
electronics, high-voltage technology, and electric
power systems, and the Ph.D. degree from the
Power Electronic SystemsLaboratory, ETH Zürich,
in 2018, with a focus on solid-state transformers and
their optimization, calorimetric loss measurement
methods, advanced medium-voltage insulation, and
protection of 10-kV silicon-carbide devices.
In 2019, he joined the ABB Research Center, Baden, Switzerland, as a
Scientist in the ﬁeld of power electronics.
Dr. Rothmund has been awarded the JESTPE First Prize Paper Award
2019 for his research on a 99% efﬁcient 10-kV silicon-carbide-based
7-kV-to-400-V dc/dc solid-state transformer.
Mitrofan Curti (Member, IEEE) received the M.Sc.
degree in electrical engineering from the Warsaw
University of Technology, Warsaw, Poland, in 2014.
Later the same year, he joined the Electromechanics
and Power Electronics Group of Eindhoven Univer-
sity of Technology. He received the Ph.D. degree
from the Eindhoven University of Technology, Eind-
hoven, The Netherlands, in 2019.
He is currently an Assistant Professor with the

Elena A. Lomonova (Senior Member, IEEE) grad-
uated (cum laude) in electromechanical and con-
trol systems from the Moscow Aviation Institute
(National Research University), Moscow, Russia,
and received the Ph.D. degree (cum laude) from
the same institute in 1993, working on powertrain
and control systems for autonomous vehicles with
multilevel power supply subsystems for on-board
loads and laser equipment.
She started her industrial career with the research
and development company Astrophysics, Moscow,
from 1982 to 1987. Afterward, she moved to MAI and was active in research,
education, and industrial projects from 1987 to 1997. In 1998, she was with
the Delft University of Technology (TUDelft), Delft, The Netherlands. She
joined the Eindhoven University of Technology, Eindhoven, The Netherlands,
in 2000. In 2009, she was appointed a full-time Professor and the Chair of
the Electromechanics and Power Electronics Group, Eindhoven University
of Technology. Her chair focuses on fundamental and applied research
on enabling energy conversion theory, methods and technologies for high
precision, automotive, and medical systems. She is the author or a coauthor of
more than 300 scientiﬁc publications and more than 15 patents. Her research
interests include various facets of advanced mechatronics, electromechanics,
and electromagnetics, including rotary electrical machines, drives, and linear
and planar actuation systems.
Dr. Lomonova holds the prestigious awards—Nagamori (Japan, 2016) and
Lifetime Contributions to Magnetics (Cambridge, U.K., 2019).
